notesStmt.note: The codex has been trimmed and it became smaller in size than the other three volumes.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

supportDesc.extent: 124 folios (+4 unfoliated flyleaves at the beginning and at the end).

collation.p: 10 quires (catchwords, signatures have been trimmed off). Quires are of 12 leaves each,Several unfoliated paper flyleaves (of Christian provenance, with watermark of two lions holding a banner) at the beginning and at the end.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Sefardi square script, punctuated through the main text and unpunctuated through the masoretic notes, of the 14th century.

decoDesc.decoNote: Several pen-decorated signs, indicating the beginning of the pericope. Several pen-decorated inital and middle-letters, especially ל of the uppermost line of the text. Masorah in micrographical form.

binding.p: Post-1600 Harleian binding, red leather with gold tooling, marble paper pastedown. Spine: 'Bible I. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Harl. Ms. 5498.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: Inscription by Edward Harley's librarian, Humfrey Wanley, 28 July 1725 (folio 2r of volume 1). The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta, née Cavendish Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
